title: David Hay
text:
David Hay (born 29 January 1948) is a Scottish former <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and <a href="manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>. He broke into the <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> team in the late 1960s, as one of a generation of players who continued a highly successful era for the club. A contract dispute between Hay and Celtic led to him being transferred to <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> in 1974. He played in over 100 league games for Chelsea, but was forced to retire in 1979 due to a detached retina. Hay appeared in 27 international matches for <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a>, and was selected for their <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1974 FIFA World Cup</a> squad.
After retiring as a player, Hay entered football management with <a href="Motherwell%20F.C.">Motherwell</a> in 1981. He led them to a promotion in <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20in%20Scottish%20football">1981–82</a>, but left the club at the end of the season. He was then appointed Celtic manager in 1983, and enjoyed some success as they won the <a href="1984%E2%80%9385%20Scottish%20Cup">1984–85 Scottish Cup</a> and the <a href="list%20of%20Scottish%20football%20champions">Scottish league championship</a> in 1985–86. In the 1990s he returned to Celtic as Chief Scout and later Assistant General manager.
Hay also won the <a href="list%20of%20Norwegian%20football%20league%20champions">Norwegian league championship</a> during a brief stint with <a href="Lillestr%C3%B8m%20SK">Lillestrøm SK</a>. He subsequently worked for <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren</a>, <a href="Livingston%20F.C.">Livingston</a> and <a href="Dunfermline%20Athletic%20F.C.">Dunfermline Athletic</a>.
Playing career.
After completing his secondary education at <a href="St%20Mirin%27s%20Academy">St Mirin's Academy</a> in Paisley, Hay signed for <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> in 1966. He became one of the "<a href="Quality%20Street%20Gang%20%28Celtic%20F.C.%29">Quality Street Gang</a>" reserve team which eventually took the places of the ageing <a href="Lisbon%20Lions">Lisbon Lions</a>. He made his league debut on 6 March 1968 against Aberdeen going on to make 230 appearances for Celtic scoring 12 goals, winning 5 League Championships, 3 Scottish Cups and 1 League Cup. After playing for <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> in the <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1974 World Cup</a> in West Germany, and following a dispute with Celtic, he was transferred to <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> for a club record £225,000. Initially signed as a direct replacement for Alan Hudson in midfield, he adopted a more defensive role in the young Chelsea side that emerged following their relegation a year later. In 1979 a serious knee injury forced him to retire from the game as a player. He had also suffered problems with a <a href="detached%20retina">detached retina</a> and eventually lost full vision in his right eye. He won a total 27 caps for Scotland.
Management career.
Motherwell.
His first venture into football management was when he took over the reins at <a href="Motherwell%20F.C.">Motherwell</a> in 1981 following <a href="Ally%20MacLeod">Ally MacLeod</a>. He led Well to the <a href="Scottish%20First%20Division">Scottish First Division</a> title and promotion to the <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20Division">Scottish Premier Division</a>. He left at the end of the 1981-82 season.
Celtic.
Hay succeeded <a href="Billy%20McNeill">Billy McNeill</a> as Celtic manager in 1983, winning the <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a> in <a href="1984%E2%80%9385%20Scottish%20Cup">1985</a> and the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20Premier%20Division">Premier Division</a> in dramatic fashion in <a href="1985%E2%80%9386%20Scottish%20Premier%20Division">1986</a>. Celtic won their final game 5–0 against <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren</a> at Love Street but needed <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.">Hearts</a>, who were league leaders and favourites to lift the trophy, to lose to <a href="Dundee%20F.C.">Dundee</a> at <a href="Dens%20Park">Dens Park</a>. <a href="Albert%20Kidd">Albert Kidd</a> secured the victory for Dundee with two goals and Celtic were crowned champions. After Celtic failed to win a trophy in <a href="1986%E2%80%9387%20in%20Scottish%20football">1986–87</a>, Hay left Celtic. He was asked to resign, but refused, so he was sacked and was replaced by McNeill.
Lillestrom SK.
In 1989, Hay ventured to Norway and led <a href="Lillestrom%20SK">Lillestrom SK</a> to the <a href="Norwegian%20Premier%20League">Norwegian Premier League</a> championship.
St Mirren.
In 1991, Hay took on Paisley club <a href="St%20Mirren%20F.C.">St Mirren</a> but left a year later.
Return to Celtic.
Hay became chief scout at Celtic in 1994, and was responsible for identifying players such as <a href="Jorge%20Cadete">Jorge Cadete</a>, <a href="Paolo%20di%20Canio">Paolo di Canio</a> and <a href="Pierre%20van%20Hooijdonk">Pierre van Hooijdonk</a> who signed for the club. He became Assistant General manager to <a href="Jock%20Brown">Jock Brown</a> in 1997, but left in 1998 in acrimonious circumstances.
Livingston.
Hay teamed up with <a href="Jim%20Leishman">Jim Leishman</a> in 2000 as co-managers of <a href="Livingston%20F.C.">Livingston</a>, and led the club to the <a href="Scottish%20First%20Division">Scottish First Division</a> title at the end of 2000-01, and the club's first promotion to the <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">Scottish Premier League</a>. Their debut season in the top flight in 2001-02 earned them their first qualification into Europe with a <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a> place. The 2002-03 season was less impressive and they both stepped down from the management position, although they both stayed at the club. Brazilian <a href="Marcio%20Maximo">Marcio Maximo Barcellos</a> took over.
Hay returned to the manager's job shortly into 2003-04 season, this time in sole charge, taking over from Marcio Maximo after just 9 games of the season. Hay went on to win the <a href="Scottish%20League%20Cup">Scottish League Cup</a> while the club was in administration, beating heavy favourites <a href="Hibernian%20F.C.">Hibernian</a> (who beat <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> and <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a> en route to the final). Despite this success, the veteran boss was released at the end of the season to be replaced by <a href="Allan%20Preston">Allan Preston</a>, one of his first team coaches, by new chairman, Pearse Flynn of the Lionheart Consortium.
Dunfermline Athletic.
Hay was then appointed manager of <a href="Dunfermline%20Athletic%20F.C.">Dunfermline Athletic</a>, succeeding <a href="Jimmy%20Calderwood">Jimmy Calderwood</a>. He rejoined with <a href="Jim%20Leishman">Jim Leishman</a> who was the Fife club's <a href="Director%20of%20Football">Director of Football</a>. He was sacked near the end of the season with the club struggling in the <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">Scottish Premier League</a>.
After management.
Hay rejoined <a href="Livingston%20FC">Livingston</a> on 16 June 2008 in an advisory role. He briefly became interim manager in 2009 after <a href="Paul%20Hegarty">Paul Hegarty</a> was suspended by the club.
In 2015 Hay returned to Celtic as a director of the Celtic Pools, which raises money for the youth academy. He has also worked in a business development role for New College Lanarkshire.
